                                            By

                                                    Matt Latimer


                Getty

            By 
Rachael Bade

09/16/15, 12:44 PM EDT
Two senior Senate Democrats dismissed Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn’ s call for a special counsel to probe the Hillary Clinton emails controversy, calling it a political ploy. 
Judiciary and Intelligence committee ranking Democrats Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.) and Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) said the No. 2 Senate Republican’s demand that Attorney General Loretta Lynch appoint an outside investigator would just be a waste of taxpayer money.
“Calls for a special counsel to review Secretary Clinton’s emails are entirely unwarranted,” Feinstein said in a Wednesday statement. “Instead of wasting more taxpayer dollars, the process in place to review and release Secretary Clinton’s emails, which she has welcomed, should be allowed to continue. Calls for a special counsel are purely political and completely unnecessary.”
“I do not question the integrity or ability of Attorney General Lynch or FBI Director Comey – and certainly do not see any conflict or extraordinary circumstances that would warrant a Special Counsel,” Leahy said in an emailed comment to POLITICO. “Such a suggestion is nothing more than yet another political ploy that would compound the growing pile of taxpayer dollars that already has been wasted on this politically motivated quest.” 
 Those remarks come just a day after Cornyn (R-Texas) wrote Lynch asking that she consider an outside investigator because Clinton is a former Obama Administration official and the frontrunner for the Democratic ticket for the White House. 
Republicans have grown increasingly skeptical that Justice Department political appointees will allow the elevation of the FBI’s probe of classified documents into a criminal matter if necessary, or to empanel a grand jury, due to the clout Clinton holds in Washington's Democratic circles.

HILLARY CLINTON EMAILS

            By 
Rachael Bade

Outside counsels have been used before to side step the appearance of a conflict-of-interest. But Justice has dismissed the GOP’s calls for such prosecutors numerous times before— and few expect Lynch to make such a move, which would affectively take the entire issue out of the Justice Department’s control.
Leahy also noted that there’s been “no indication” that the Clinton probe, currently more of a systematic review of how State documents were treated rather than a focus on her specifically, has been elevated to a criminal matter — so there’s, therefore, no need for special counsel. 
 In the hallway in recent weeks when asked about the Clinton scandal, the former Judiciary chairman grumbled about the cost of the House Select Committee on Benghazi. Feinstein likewise in her statement chastised the panel for “attacks” against Clinton, pointing out the previous congressional committees have already probed the matter and have not found any wrongdoing. The Benghazi committee, however, has actually not called for special prosecutor.
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
title: Sens. Feinstein, Leahy blast GOP calls for Clinton special counsel
